author: Steven Swinford
title: Retreat on rate rises as Philip Hammond considers extra funding for independent shops and small companies
text:
News Retreat on rate rises as Philip Hammond considers extra funding for independent shops and small companies Philip Hammond is examining plans to offer extra funding to independent retailers and small companies Credit: RODGER BOSCH/Getty Steven Swinford , Deputy Political Editor 21 February 2017 • 11:25pm 
M inisters are set to give way over business rates and pay hundreds of millions of pounds in compensation to those worst hit by the tax following a revolt by Conservative MPs. 
Philip Hammond, the Chancellor, is examining plans to offer extra funding to independent retailers and small companies facing huge increases in business rates. 
Bills for the coming year are due to go out over a five-week period starting on Friday. 
The move comes as Sajid Javid, the Communities Secretary, is expected to tell MPs that he understands concerns about the impact of the rises and that the Government will do what it can to help those hardest hit. Sajid Javid has come under fire over the changes Credit: Jack Taylor/Getty 
H is speech represents a significant change of tone after he triggered a backlash from backbenchers at the weekend by blaming criticism of the rates on a “relentless campaign of distortions and half truths”. 
Tory MPs said that Mr Javid’s reputation had been significantly “damaged” by his handling of the business rate changes, with one minister drawing comparisons with the introduction of the poll tax under Margaret Thatcher. 
However, Conservative allies of Mr Javid said that he had been set up as the “fall guy” for Mr Hammond and that criticism was “deeply unfair, because this is being led by the Treasury”. 
Theresa May’s spokesman said she had full confidence in Mr Javid. Business rates changes - LA 
M eanwhile, ministers were accused of treating small businesses like criminals after figures showed that one in four firms in parts of the UK has been taken to court over unpaid rates. 
A survey by CVS Business Rent & Rates Specialists found that nearly 200,000 businesses were hauled before a magistrate in 2015-16. 
In three areas – Middlesbrough, Thurrock and Waltham Forest – a quarter of firms faced legal proceedings over unpaid business rates, and experts say that the number unable to pay will increase significantly when new rates come into force. 
The new rates, which take effect in April and represent the first change in almost a decade, will result in companies paying sums that have been calculated to take into account the rise in property prices since 2008. Credit: Steve Back /Barcroft Images 
I t means many businesses in the South East will face soaring bills while others in areas where high street rental prices have fallen will benefit. 
Mark Field, a vice-chairman of the Conservative Party, last week said that Mr Hammond must back down from the “looming nightmare” of higher business rates in Tory heartlands. 
Mr Hammond indicated on Monday in a meeting with Tory MPs that he was “alive” to the impact that the changes would have on high street shops and was “open” about ways to offer support. 
He is considering plans for new funds to help independent retailers and businesses facing significant rises in business rates. Business rates changes - postcode 
T he extra money, expected to total hundreds of millions of pounds, will not be available for larger companies with chains of shops, pubs and restaurants. 
According to official figures, the Government will raise an additional £1 billion from the tax next year, while borrowing is expected to be up to £10 billion lower than expected. 
Conservative MPs said that the positive economic figures suggest Mr Hammond will have significantly more room for manoeuvre than expected. 
The Chancellor has also indicated that he wants more fundamental reform of the system to ensure online retailers such as Amazon do not benefit to the detriment of the high street. There are fears business rate changes could be detrimental to the high street Credit: Martin Rickett /PA 
C riticism of the policy has intensified. One minister compared it with the poll tax revolt. 
“Everyone said it was fine before the bills landed, that there would be lots of winners, then reality hit,” the minister said. 
“There’s a growing realisation about the seriousness of what’s to come.” Tory MPs also warned Mr Javid that he has “lost credibility”. 
One said: “He’s damaged. He came out of the referendum very badly after flirting with Brexit, then backing Remain. This has only damaged his credibility further.” 
However, a Tory MP who supports Mr Javid said: “It feels like Sajid is being the fall guy here when actually he’s not the person that sets the rates. Everyone knows that’s Philip Hammond and yet they are pointing the finger at Saj. It feels deeply unfair because this is led by Treasury.”
